awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  No-code electric grid analytics platform for predictive maintenance planning and emergency response
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in helping in the design of a cost-effective resiliency strategy for defense against the impacts of climate change. Today, the U.S. experiences significantly more weather events imposing substantially more financial burden compared to 40 years ago. As climate change accelerates, communities will be forced to endure increased financial burdens protecting against and mitigating its impacts. Research carried out in this SBIR project is intended to help reduce these expenses. Utilities, cities, insurance companies, and municipalities are stakeholders in these resiliency efforts and will be looking for new tools to help mitigate the effects and reduce the costs of climate change. The research in this project will enable utilities to reduce resilience-related costs and reduce impact on businesses and local economies due to power outages.  Such actions may benefit all communities, particularly poorer and marginal communities that often endure the worst impacts of climate change.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to develop predictive analytics for tropical storms and wildfires and to integrate this functionality into a power grid analytics software platform.  Three artificial intelligence/machine learning (AI/ML) tools will be implemented, qualitatively expanding on early prototypes: (1) in the satellite imagery (SI) domain, an optimized combination of deep-learning neural network (DLNN) techniques will be trained on large-scale satellite images, resulting in the world's first tree growth tracking and species identification tool; (2) a "Virtual Wind Tunnel" (VWT) will be augmented with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and empirical physics modeling to estimate the probability of trees damaging power transmission assets during weather events forecast; and (3) towards a no-code user interface, existing natural language processing (NLP) will be expanded, with the goal of processing queries from engineers unfamiliar with AI/ML. Key questions addressed by the research include whether the software platform will be able to adapt to new utility customers and service areas without sacrificing performance, whether increased data resolution can be effectively leveraged to better predictive power, and whether the platform can continuously improve event prediction over time by learning from historical grid data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to develop predictive analytics for tropical storms and to integrate this functionality into a power grid analytics software platform. Key questions addressed by the research include whether the software platform would be able to adapt to new utility customers and service areas without sacrificing performance, whether increased data resolution can be effectively leveraged to better predictive power and whether the platform can continuously improve events prediction over time by learning from historical grid data.  The project team developed, and field tested with 3 separate customers in Alabama, North Carolina and South Carolina. With all 3 customers and across the 3 service areas, the platform produced predictive insights without sacrificing performance. The platform also leveraged high resolution imagery as well as historical reliability for better predictive analytics. With feedback from the 2 utilities and one city customer, the platform is being refined to focus on the outcomes that matter most to utilities, namely, achieving less risk with less spend by practicing proactive hazard mitigation be dealing with risks visualized on the platform, before they become disaster or catastrophic incidents.

Major Activities: In this project, we successfully set up a scalable system for ingesting high resolution satellite imagery and deploying a resiliency-focused analytics pipeline to estimate the tree health and the risk posed by these trees to critical infrastructure.

Specific Objectives: The specific objectives of our project were (1) Large-scale interpretation of high-resolution satellite imagery. (2) Integration of satellite imagery with meteorological data (3) Training Sync EI platform for no-code operator interaction.

Significant Results: We were able to meet or exceed our objectives as we have made our imagery-ingestion platform fairly automated through the use of APIs. We have estimated tree health for three cities in North Carolina, and our results are being validated by ground crew.

Key outcomes or other achievements: An interactive no-code dashboard that our end-users can use to perform smart vegetation management analytics using satellite powered data and AI.

The project results have been disseminated to the wider communities of interest through interactive web-dashboards (see Figure 1 for one example) that our end-users can use using their laptops or mobile devices. We are members of professional associations in which communities of interest are also members. These associations, such as the E4 Carolinas Group, provides opportunities for us to share our work with all 140 members of the group. We have also presented in the tech vendor day of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association (NRECA) with its 900 members. We have also presented at Several Innovation Council meetings of various groups, such as CPS Energy in San Antonio, Texas.


Last Modified: 05/27/2022
Modified by: Sayonsom Chanda
